G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: The Court has subject-matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, which vests the Superior Court with original jurisdiction of civil actions where the likely recovery exceeds $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 2 because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts, and both Plaintiff and Defendant reside in Hampden County.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others arising from his conduct.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states, as a general principle of Massachusetts tort law, that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, conditioned on foreseeability of the risk. This directly aligns with the proposition that under Massachusetts law each person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm arising from his conduct. The opinion uses this general duty as the doctrinal basis for recognizing a specific duty in the firearm-storage context.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.relevant_excerpt: "We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor."

*Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.*.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others arising from his conduct.
*Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.*.support_reasoning: The court explicitly articulates a general negligence principle that aligns with the claimed proposition, stating that a basic principle of negligence law is that everyone has a duty to refrain from affirmative acts that unreasonably expose others to a risk of harm. It then applies that principle to hold that Paramount and Saxon owed a duty of reasonable care to members of the public, including the decedent, regarding the production, exhibition, and advertising of movies. This directly supports the idea that Massachusetts law recognizes a general duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm arising from one’s conduct.
*Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.*.relevant_excerpt: “A basic principle of negligence law is that ordinarily everyone has a duty to refrain from affirmative acts that unreasonably expose others to a risk of harm. Thus, we have held that a keeper of a tavern owes to travelers on the highway a duty of care with respect to the furnishing of alcoholic beverages to his customers… In keeping with that principle, Paramount and Saxon owed a duty of reasonable care to members of the public including the plaintiff’s decedent with respect to the producing, exhibiting, and advertising of movies.”

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: A landowner or possessor of property, including a co-occupant of a shared driveway, owes persons lawfully present a duty to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect them from foreseeable risks of harm.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the general rule that an owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, including the obligation to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of unreasonable dangers. Although the case ultimately holds there is no duty to alter an adjacent state highway, the court affirmatively endorses the general landowner-duty principle that matches the proposition (apart from the added, more specific reference to a ‘co-occupant of a shared driveway,’ which this case does not address).
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.” 420 Mass. at 743.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.proposition: A landowner or possessor of property, including a co-occupant of a shared driveway, owes persons lawfully present a duty to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect them from foreseeable risks of harm.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is a concurrence focused on the treatment of trespassers versus licensees/invitees, but it is written in agreement with the majority’s abandonment of rigid entrant-status categories in favor of a more general negligence standard. The main *Mounsey* decision (at 363 Mass. 707–08) is well known for holding that landowners/occupiers owe a duty of reasonable care to persons lawfully on the premises, which encompasses maintaining the premises in reasonably safe condition against foreseeable risks. Although the excerpt itself does not spell out the full duty, the case as a whole supports the proposition for lawful entrants, including co-occupants using shared areas.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.relevant_excerpt: [From the concurrence] "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors."

*Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u2.proposition: In addition, a person who creates or maintains a condition on or near real property that poses a foreseeable risk of injury to others using that property has a duty to take reasonable steps to prevent such harm.
*Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u2.support_reasoning: The case rejects, rather than recognizes, a duty on homeowners/social hosts to control or prevent dangerous acts by others on their property when they did not create, provide, or control the dangerous condition. The court emphasizes that landowner duty regarding property conditions concerns preexisting physical conditions and that, absent a special relationship or creation of the danger, there is no affirmative duty to protect against third-party conduct. Thus it undercuts a broad proposition that anyone who merely maintains a foreseeable risk-creating condition on or near real property must take reasonable steps to prevent harm.
*Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition refers to preexisting physical conditions… There is no room in this branch of tort law for the plaintiff’s contention that the fireworks somehow constituted a physical condition on the defendants’ land for which they were responsible, because of the undisputed fact that the fireworks were brought to the party, and then lit, by third persons.… [O]ur policy… has been to reject claims of liability against social hosts in negligence, in the absence of a recognized legal basis requiring them to protect guests.”

*O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass. 201.proposition: In addition, a person who creates or maintains a condition on or near real property that poses a foreseeable risk of injury to others using that property has a duty to take reasonable steps to prevent such harm.
*O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass. 201.support_reasoning: The case concerns the scope of a landowner’s premises-liability duty and, in particular, the ‘open and obvious danger’ doctrine as a duty‑negating principle. It does not articulate a broader rule that any person who creates or maintains a condition on or near land that poses a foreseeable risk thereby has a duty to take reasonable protective steps; instead, it emphasizes that even where a dangerous condition exists, no duty to warn or protect arises if the danger is open and obvious. Thus the opinion undercuts, rather than supports, the expansive duty formulation in the claimed proposition.
*O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass. 201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises… However, it is well established in our law of negligence that a landowner’s duty to protect lawful visitors against dangerous conditions on his property ordinarily does not extend to dangers that would be obvious to persons of average intelligence… [T]he open and obvious danger rule… operates to negate the existence of a duty of care.” (431 Mass. at 204–06)

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.proposition: The standard of care requires a person to act as a reasonably prudent person would under the circumstances.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses negligence elements, including breach of a duty to use reasonable care, causation, and damages, but it does not articulate the standard of care as "a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances." The court relies on Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 and a tort treatise for the elements of negligence without explicitly stating or analyzing the reasonably prudent person standard. Thus, this case is not direct authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989).

*Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*, 44.proposition: Defendant’s inaction after specific, repeated warnings from Plaintiff further evidences a breach of duty, as Defendant had actual knowledge of the specific risk and failed to act.
*Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*, 44.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss a defendant’s inaction after specific, repeated warnings from the plaintiff, nor does it analyze liability based on actual knowledge of a specific risk followed by failure to act. Instead, the court holds that the utility defendants owed no duty at all to the decedent because a drunk driver’s deviation from the roadway is not reasonably foreseeable under Restatement (Second) of Torts § 368. The reasoning is about the existence and scope of duty and foreseeability, not about breach shown by ignoring plaintiff warnings, so the case does not support the claimed proposition.
*Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*, 44.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that because he was intoxicated, Veilleux cannot be said to have deviated from the road in the ordinary course of travel and his deviation, which was caused by intoxication, was not, and could not have been, reasonably anticipated. Accordingly, the utility defendants owed no duty to Afarian. We therefore do not reach the question whether the pole’s placement created an unreasonable risk of harm to persons lawfully traveling on the road and to persons deviating from it in the ordinary course of travel.”

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: The type of harm suffered by Plaintiff—damage to property located in close proximity to an unsecured tall ladder susceptible to being blown over by wind—was a foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s failure to act reasonably under the circumstances.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The excerpt shows the concurring justice explicitly agreeing that the plaintiff’s injuries were *not* within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. Thus, the opinion is being used to support the opposite proposition: that the harm was not foreseeable. Nothing in the provided text suggests that damage to property near an unsecured ladder was considered a foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s conduct.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that '[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.' Ante at 640-641."

*Hopkins v. American Honda Motor Co.*, 4.raw_text: *Hopkins v. American Honda Motor Co.*, 431 Mass. 826, 830–31 (2000)
*Hopkins v. American Honda Motor Co.*, 4.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover the reasonable costs of repair and loss-of-use damages, including rental expenses, for damage negligently caused to her automobile.
*Hopkins v. American Honda Motor Co.*, 4.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Hopkins v. American Honda Motor Co. at all, but a Quincy murder case (Commonwealth v. Diaz) concerning extradition/deportation issues and a mental impairment defense. It does not address tort damages, motor vehicles, repair costs, or loss-of-use/rental expenses. Therefore, this opinion cannot provide authority for the stated Massachusetts automobile damage damages rule.
*Hopkins v. American Honda Motor Co.*, 4.relevant_excerpt: The opinion discusses jurisdiction following deportation and extradition procedures, mental impairment, and jury instructions on manslaughter and premeditated murder. There is no discussion of property damage, motor vehicle repair, or loss-of-use damages in the provided text.

*Wallace v. Ludwig*, 292 Mass. 251, 255\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover the reasonable costs of repair and loss-of-use damages, including rental expenses, for damage negligently caused to her automobile.
*Wallace v. Ludwig*, 292 Mass. 251, 255\.support_reasoning: The opinion in Wallace v. Ludwig does not concern property damage to an automobile or any measure of damages for vehicle repair or loss of use. It deals exclusively with personal injury and wrongful death causation and related damages flowing from bodily injury. Because the case neither mentions automobile repair costs nor rental or loss-of-use damages, it cannot serve as authority for the stated proposition about recovery of repair and rental expenses for damage to a car.
*Wallace v. Ludwig*, 292 Mass. 251, 255\.relevant_excerpt:
It is not necessary to recite the evidence. It warranted findings that the intestate received severe personal injuries by reason of the negligence of the defendant, that there was no contributory negligence on the part of the intestate, and that she subsequently died. Pease v. Lenssen, 286 Mass. 207.

The questions argued by the defendant relate chiefly to the death case.

*Mathis v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*, 409.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks any diminution in value of her Vehicle, if proven at trial, together with all other consequential damages reasonably flowing from Defendant’s negligence.
*Mathis v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*, 409.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with comparative negligence, duties to child trespassers, and amendment of pleadings; it does not discuss recoverable categories of damages such as diminution in value of a vehicle or consequential property damages. There is no language about the measure of damages, types of compensable loss, or property valuation. Therefore, the case does not provide authority for a plaintiff’s entitlement to diminution in value of a vehicle and other consequential damages flowing from negligence.
*Mathis v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*, 409.relevant_excerpt: The comparative negligence statute states in part that, “[c]ontributory negligence shall not bar recovery in any action by any person or legal representative to recover damages for negligence resulting in death or in injury to person or property, if such negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the person or persons against whom recovery is sought, but any damages allowed shall be diminished in proportion to the amount of negligence attributable to the person for whose injury, damage or death recovery is made.” G. L. c. 231, § 85 (1988...

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under G.L. c. 231, § 85, any comparative negligence of Plaintiff, if alleged by Defendant, would not bar recovery unless it exceeded 50%, and there is no evidence that Plaintiff was negligent in any respect; in any event, Plaintiff’s negligence, if any, was substantially less than that of Defendant.

*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in bringing about Plaintiff’s damages.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.support_reasoning: The opinion does address negligence, causation, and proximate cause, but it does so to hold that the Commonwealth’s alleged negligence was not, as a matter of law, the proximate (legal) cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. The court concludes the chain of causation was broken by intervening acts of the INS, and orders dismissal of the negligence claims. Thus, the case stands for the opposite of the proposition that the defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in bringing about the plaintiff’s damages.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.relevant_excerpt: “Although deciding the issue of causation on a motion to dismiss may present the exception rather than the rule, in light of the intervening events present and acknowledged in the complaint, there is no set of facts that the plaintiffs could prove to support a conclusion that the Commonwealth’s decision to parole MacNeil to the INS deportation warrant in 1987 was the proximate cause of Kent’s injuries in 1995. The Commonwealth’s motion to dismiss the claims for negligence should have been allowed.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff is therefore entitled to judgment against Defendant for all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, together with statutory interest and costs, pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest in tort actions) and G.L. c. 235, § 8 (post-judgment interest).

G.L. c. 235, \u00a7 8.proposition: Plaintiff is therefore entitled to judgment against Defendant for all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, together with statutory interest and costs, pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest in tort actions) and G.L. c. 235, § 8 (post-judgment interest).
